awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Reverberating Responses to Trophic Cascades across Ecosystems: from Land to Streams and Back Again
awd_abstract_narration:
The many interconnected relationships between predators and prey in a food web can link seemingly distant organisms and processes.  This study explores how the influence of top predators in a terrestrial environment is linked across ecosystem boundaries to impact primary production and food webs in aquatic environments. This study also explores how aquatic ecosystem responses to predators can reverberate back out of the stream to impact terrestrial predators that rely on the export of emerging adult insects from the stream. Cross-ecosystem food web connections will be studied at three different National Parks (Zion, Rocky Mountain, and Yellowstone National Parks), thereby providing replication at large spatial scales and leveraging the opportunities that National Parks provide to educate the public about food web ecology and the role of top predators in structuring our ecosystems.  This research will be the first of its kind to investigate reverberating effects of trophic cascades whereby indirect effects may cross ecosystem boundaries (terrestrial to aquatic) and then subsequently reverberate back to animals and plants in the original ecosystem (aquatic back to terrestrial).  This work will provide a more complete picture of how the loss of top predatory species worldwide may be indirectly influencing many distantly connected species.

Previous investigations have demonstrated the indirect role of top predators (e.g., wolves in Yellowstone Park and mountain lions in Zion National Park) in control of riparian vegetation along streams.  In addition, streams and riparian zones are connected by well-understood processes of material and organism exchange, making them ideal systems to identify and quantify trophic reverberations.  The study will be conducted in streams and adjacent riparian zones and will encompass (1) streamside ungulate browsing and riparian plant communities, (2) community composition and abundance of in-stream biota, quantification of terrestrial fluxes (organic matter and invertebrate) fluxes to streams, and diets of stream biota, and (3) emergent adult aquatic insects in the riparian zone and the response of spiders and bats. These riparian insectivores serve as a bellwether for changes in stream insect emergence and stream-riparian linkages. In each park, replicate study sites will be established along streams with and without controls on ungulate browsing of riparian woody vegetation.  By comparing within and across three national parks, this study will yield a greater understanding of how community and landscape context may mediate the strength, or even sign, of reverberating responses to terrestrial top-down control of ungulate browsing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Investigators from Idaho State University (this award) and Oregon State University (via a linked award) conducted collaborative research through which they sought to enrich ecological understanding and provide insights regarding management and conservation in the world’s first national park, Yellowstone National Park.  The 1995 reintroduction of wolves to Yellowstone has been elevated to an ecological parable, common in both textbooks and the general public’s discourse.  The story suggests that wolves “saved Yellowstone’s streams” by reducing browsing by elk and indirectly restoring streamside vegetation like willows, and that, in turn, this led to improvements in ecosystem health, including habitat characteristics like streambank stability, but also the diversity and productivity of stream and riparian organisms.  Stream-riparian ecosystems are reciprocally linked.  For example, the land feeds the stream through inputs of leaf litter and terrestrial insects that are consumed by aquatic insects and stream fishes.  In turn, streams feed the land through emergence of adult aquatic insects, which are eaten by predators like birds, bats, and spiders.  Researchers have hypothesized that, through such reciprocal linkages, restoring woody vegetation to Northern Yellowstone’s stream-riparian ecosystems has increased their overall diversity and productivity.  Previous findings supported this hypothesis for songbirds.  Yet, there had not been comprehensive investigations of the broader community of organisms nor ecosystem processes—a gap these investigators sought to address.

From 2018-2021, these investigators intensively studied eight headwater streams—four that had regrown willow/alder over the period since restoration of Northern Yellowstone’s apex predators, and four dominated by herbaceous plants like grasses.  The latter are locations heavily used by bison, which have not been limited by predation but have been increasing in the past twenty years, whereas the former experience less use by bison.  The researchers measured physical habitat, riparian plant communities and herbivory, aquatic primary production and inputs of terrestrial organic matter and invertebrates, productivity and food web interactions of aquatic invertebrates and fish, emergence of adult aquatic insects, and the community of riparian birds, bats, and spiders.

Overall, the investigators did not observe the consistent differences in stream-riparian organisms or ecosystem processes that they had expected when they compared the sites categorized by the two vegetation states.  The sites heavily used by bison tended to have lower native plant diversity and higher incidence of exotic species, but for other groups of organisms (algae, aquatic and terrestrial insects, fish, spiders, birds, bats) willow-dominated sites were often as different from one another (e.g., in terms of diversity) as they were from sites dominated by herbaceous plants, and vice versa.  In fact, for these groups of organisms the combination of sites at the larger scale of the landscape appeared to host greater diversity than any one site alone.  The researchers observed a similar pattern in terms of productivity, food-web interactions, and land-water linkages.  As expected, willow-dominated streams received more leaf litter input whereas grass-dominated sites, with more light, had more instream primary production.  However, the input of terrestrial invertebrates, the production of aquatic invertebrates and fishes, and the consumption of invertebrates by fish, as well as the emergence of aquatic insects and abundance of spiders, bats and birds—all were highly variable, and did not match expectations based on vegetation state alone.  How could such variability be explained?

The investigators found clues by carefully evaluating the traits of organisms and the tangled web of interactions connecting stream-riparian ecosystems.  For instance, despite two willow-dominated streams having similar annual aquatic invertebrate production, their fish production differed by 2.5-fold—a contrast due to one site hosting native cutthroat trout and the other non-native brook trout.  The more productive brook trout consumed virtually all of the annual aquatic invertebrate production while the cutthroat trout (which also relied more on terrestrial invertebrate prey) only consumed about 22%, a pattern documented elsewhere in the Intermountain West.  This had direct consequences for the timing and magnitude of aquatic insect emergence.  In July-August, a key period for many insectivores given Yellowstone’s short growing season, the site with cutthroat trout had nearly twice the aquatic insect emergence flux.  It also had twice the amount of bat activity, especially little brown bats that hawk emerging insects.  This illustrates a recurring finding from the study: traits that influenced one interaction mediated subsequent linkages, and effects propagated from land, to water, and back to the land. 

This study's findings question the simple hypothesis that restoration of apex predators improved Yellowstone’s stream-riparian ecosystems in a homogeneous fashion, raising other possibilities.  One possibility is that, given more time and increasing bison, more evidence may arise that they limit ecosystem recovery and even increase vulnerability of native biodiversity in locations they frequent.  Alternatively, the heterogeneity these investigators observed may represent a shifting mosaic of conditions that itself contributes to long-term resilience in the face of major environmental changes.  Time—as well as ongoing research by this group and others—will tell.
